body:
### Problem

Neovim crashes.

### Steps to reproduce

```
printf 'Â”' | nvim --embed
```

### Expected behavior

No crash. Note that while this reproducer may seem contrived, it actually comes from an actual use case (piping messagepack commands to an embedded neovim from the shell).


This crash may or may not be related to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21604 .

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

8e6971695383047ee5ba2921c91d98acb18c6d7a

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

N/A

### Operating system/version

linux

### Terminal name/version

N/A

### $TERM environment variable

N/A

### Installation

Built from source

comment_data.body:
So I came across the exact same issue, but my payload was valid msgpack (but slightly invalid rpc because I made a mistake).

Here is a trace:

```gdb
Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.
0x00007f6d37f94fec in __pthread_kill_implementation () from /gnu/store/gsjczqir1wbz8p770zndrpw4rnppmxi3-glibc-2.35/lib/libc.so.6

(ins)(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007f6d37f94fec in __pthread_kill_implementation () from /gnu/store/gsjczqir1wbz8p770zndrpw4rnppmxi3-glibc-2.35/lib/libc.so.6
#1  0x00007f6d37f4b202 in raise () from /gnu/store/gsjczqir1wbz8p770zndrpw4rnppmxi3-glibc-2.35/lib/libc.so.6
#2  0x00007f6d37f3645b in abort () from /gnu/store/gsjczqir1wbz8p770zndrpw4rnppmxi3-glibc-2.35/lib/libc.so.6
#3  0x00007f6d37f36395 in __assert_fail_base.cold () from /gnu/store/gsjczqir1wbz8p770zndrpw4rnppmxi3-glibc-2.35/lib/libc.so.6
#4  0x00007f6d37f444d2 in __assert_fail () from /gnu/store/gsjczqir1wbz8p770zndrpw4rnppmxi3-glibc-2.35/lib/libc.so.6
#5  0x00000000005f9771 in rbuffer_consumed (buf=buf@entry=0xe4b880, count=<optimized out>) at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/rbuffer.c:144
#6  0x00000000005f9792 in rbuffer_consumed_compact (buf=0xe4b880, count=<optimized out>) at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/rbuffer.c:166
#7  0x00000000005b3325 in receive_msgpack (stream=<optimized out>, rbuf=0xe4b880, c=<optimized out>, data=0xe4b0a0, eof=<optimized out>)
    at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/msgpack_rpc/channel.c:305
#8  0x0000000000518040 in read_event (argv=argv@entry=0x7ffd06e966d0) at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/event/rstream.c:192
#9  0x000000000051812c in invoke_read_cb (stream=stream@entry=0xe4b0c0, count=count@entry=14, eof=eof@entry=false)
    at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/event/rstream.c:205
#10 0x000000000051967c in read_cb (uvstream=<optimized out>, cnt=14, buf=<optimized out>) at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/event/rstream.c:134
#11 0x00007f6d3813e7b7 in ?? () from /gnu/store/f8xqz1n89vdm6cf609l6fmqrhi979xbp-libuv-1.43.0/lib/libuv.so.1
#12 0x00007f6d3813f058 in ?? () from /gnu/store/f8xqz1n89vdm6cf609l6fmqrhi979xbp-libuv-1.43.0/lib/libuv.so.1
#13 0x00007f6d38146ad5 in ?? () from /gnu/store/f8xqz1n89vdm6cf609l6fmqrhi979xbp-libuv-1.43.0/lib/libuv.so.1
#14 0x00007f6d38134474 in uv_run () from /gnu/store/f8xqz1n89vdm6cf609l6fmqrhi979xbp-libuv-1.43.0/lib/libuv.so.1
#15 0x00000000005145df in loop_uv_run (loop=loop@entry=0x7dbba0 <main_loop>, ms=-1, once=once@entry=true)
    at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/event/loop.c:65
#16 0x00000000005151b8 in loop_poll_events (loop=0x7dbba0 <main_loop>, ms=<optimized out>) at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/event/loop.c:87
#17 0x00000000005e4196 in inbuf_poll (ms=ms@entry=-1, events=events@entry=0xe014e0) at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/os/input.c:459
#18 0x00000000005e4697 in os_inchar (buf=0x0, maxlen=0, ms=<optimized out>, tb_change_cnt=1, events=0xe014e0)
    at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/os/input.c:143
#19 0x0000000000654ef4 in state_enter (s=0x7ffd06e99bd0) at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/state.c:78
#20 0x00000000005b8fc6 in normal_enter (cmdwin=<optimized out>, noexmode=<optimized out>) at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/normal.c:497
#21 0x00000000004581f4 in main (argc=<optimized out>, argv=<optimized out>) at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/main.c:641
```

The assertion being hit in line 144 is 

```
assert(count && count <= buf->size);
```

gdb also shows us a bit more about the buffer

```
(ins)(gdb) p buf->size 
$4 = 14
(ins)(gdb) p buf->data
$14 = (void *) 0xe4b0c0
(ins)(gdb) x/14xb buf->data
0xe4b0c0:       0x01    0x00    0x00    0x00    0x00    0x00    0x00    0x00
0xe4b0c8:       0xc0    0xb0    0xe4    0x00    0x00    0x00
```

That data does not look like my msgpack payload, the size is correct in that my raw msgpack is 14 bytes long (hex 9400a57265716964a46e616d6590).

Going up the stack trace, the count value has been optimized out and I lacked the source files when I started gdb, but hopefully I loaded them properly. The original caller is receive_msgpack in line 305, and consumed is just size - p->read_size.

```gdb
(ins)(gdb) up
#7  0x00000000005b3325 in receive_msgpack (stream=<optimized out>, rbuf=0xe4b880, c=<optimized out>, data=0xe4b0a0, eof=<optimized out>)
    at /tmp/guix-build-neovim-0.9.1.drv-0/source/src/nvim/msgpack_rpc/channel.c:305
305       rbuffer_consumed_compact(rbuf, consumed);
(ins)(gdb) list
300       size_t size = 0;
301       p->read_ptr = rbuffer_read_ptr(rbuf, &size);
302       p->read_size = size;
303       parse_msgpack(channel);
304       size_t consumed = size - p->read_size;
305       rbuffer_consumed_compact(rbuf, consumed);
306
307     end:
308       channel_decref(channel);
309     }
```

However it looks like consumed will end up begin 0, which would explain the failed assert

```gdb
(ins)(gdb) p size
$19 = 14
(ins)(gdb) p p->read_size 
$20 = 14
```

Still need to dig inside rbuffer_read_ptr to see what is happening.

I'm pretty sure I've hit exactly this with a plugin I wrote in Rust and it seems to be down to how Rust chooses to flush it's buffers. I've tracked it down to that Rust sometimes will send just this bytes snippet:
```[94, 00, 0A]```
rather than the following more complete which works fine:
```['94', '00', '0A', 'A9', '6E', '76', '69', '6D', '5F', '65', '78', '65', '63', '92', 'D9', '38', '73', '69', '67', '6E', '20', '70', '6C', '61', '63', '65', '20', '31', '31', '35', '37', '38', '33', '31', '20', '6C', '69', '6E', '65', '3D', '35', '30', '20', '6E', '61', '6D', '65', '3D', '56', '61', '64', '72', '65', '42', '72', '65', '61', '6B', '70', '6F', '69', '6E', '74', '20', '62', '75', '66', '66', '65', '72', '3D', '31', 'C2']```
I'd say whatever is connecting should be able to flush buffers however it chooses and Neovim should support this, but I hit the above error: `Assertion ``count && count <= buf->size'`
If I remove this assertion everything works fine, and I think it's even only the `count` assertion so I can use the plugin with this line removed, but ideally I'd rather not long term ofc.

Indeed I can trigger it with the following as per the above:
```
$ echo -e -n '\x94\x00\x0a' | ./build/bin/nvim --embed
nvim: /home/strotter/code/nvim/neovim/src/nvim/rbuffer.c:144: rbuffer_consumed: Assertion `count && count <= buf->size' failed.
Aborted (core dumped)
```
but if I remove the count assertion fine:
```
$ echo -e -n '\x94\x00\x0a' | ./build/bin/nvim --embed
$
```
There may be a better fix though, but it seems to work.

Incidentally, of the fixes I've seen in this ticket, neither of them seem to fix the problem I've hit where just removing the assertion on `count` does.
Happens to me too when running packer.nvim commands

labels.description: issue reporting a crash or segfault
labels.name: bug-crash

title: rbuffer.c:144: rbuffer_consumed: Assertion `count && count <= buf->size' failed.
